title: Universality in voting behavior

author: Marija Mitrović, School of Science, Aalto University

One of the most studied social phenomena.
Usually people study statistics of turn out rates they try to detect certain anomalies in elections.
For for instance, one year ago there was a published paper about fraud.

Authors were using data from turn out rates and the percentage of votes won by winning party to actually try to create a statistical model which will enable them to detect whether there was some fraud in these elections.
Also, people study different kind of thing like polarization and tactical voting in majoral elections.
The relation between the party sizes and temporal correlations.
Also they're trying to see.
Which type of the of the electorial systems is actually good for certain countries?
And so on.
A very uh lot of attention was on proportional elections.
These elections are usually for used for parliamentary elections in different countries.
The thing is that in the case of in the countries where you have proportional elections, the number of seats won by a party is usually proportional to the number of votes received by this party.
Country is occasionally more often divided into multi member districts.
This means that you have more than one representative from each district and in each district.
And usually these proportional elections.
Parties offer list of candidates, not just one candidate an these lists can defer in the sense of depending on the rules of these proportional elections, you can have open and semi open list system.
There is also closely system which we didn't consider in our research with openly systems.

Each party represents list of number of candidates and voters can actually choose one of these candidates and the final ranking of the candidates is decided purely by people who voted like while the number of votes they want in the same in open list.
It's a little bit different.
Case part usually represents some initial ranking of the candidates.
This means that they would prefer.
The ranking of the candidates, as it is as it is presented on the list and then voters votes giving a nominative vote for each of the candidates.
The final ranking of the candidates will depend on this initial ranking by given by the party, but some of the candidates can be kind of lucky.
One enough of the votes and then get to the top of the list.
This means that they're kind of safe.
They were chosen by people.
Now, as the final thing that you get from these elections, you get the number of votes won by a certain candidate.
Now there is a question how to look at this data and of course the first thing that pops our mind is to actually look at the distribution of votes each candidate.
Actually, since usually districts are not of the same size, this means that candidates which are in the bigger districts can win more votes then.
It's in some smaller is fixing that.

For these reasons, you have to actually normalize this number of votes and you will do this by number of all voters in that specific district, like 15 years ago there was a study from people from Brazil.
They were studying elections from Brazil and looked at the distribution of fraction of votes won by each of the candidates.
They actually showed that if you look at the elections from the two different years.

This means power along with the exponent of minus one.

As I said, each list presents a number of candidates, and people choose a party and choose a candidate on this list.
So this means that each candidate wants.
A certain number of votes which were meant actually for his party.
This means that you can actually compare the number of votes won by a certain candidate with the average number of votes won by the candidates of that party.
This is called.

If you look at the distribution of these performances of the candidate, you will see that for Italy Poland and Finland.
All of these curves.

We were wondering which of these measures is good weather.
The fraction of votes or candidate performance and also we were interested which countries and went to actually expect this.

In one category are the five countries.
Italy, Poland, Finland and Denmark and Estonia in Estonian election is actually from 2003.
In these countries the ranking of the candidates is purely decided by the people by the voters.

If you compare the elections from different years.
If you compare the curves from different countries, you will see that we have one universal curve, which is the lognormal.
The second group of countries again.
They have openly systems, but they have different rules.
For instance, in Switzerland you can cast as many votes as their member, and as there are districts in the seats given to that district.
Also in Switzerland you can actually combine.
You don't have to vote only from the candidate from one list.
